subject: RE: [junit] The right amount of testing !?
msgSnippet: Erik, ... I would call these unit tests or developer tests . ... I would call these acceptance tests or customer tests . ... I think it s all about
messageBody:
Erik,

> Actions are seperate classes, which has been tested for
> "most" possible errors and possibilities. I have one unit
> testcase for each action.

I would call these "unit tests" or "developer tests".

> Now im sitting and doing some HTTP-Unit testing of the whole
> http server, trying to login, logoff, etc. I start the server
> and connect to it as a real HTTP client, to test the functionality.

I would call these "acceptance tests" or "customer tests".

> What is the "right" amount of testing, is it best to do the
> same test but on different levels in order to make sure that
> NO strange behaviour is discovered or should I just test the
> whole flow?

I think it's all about choosing what "level" you want to be testing at
any given moment in time. Remember you need all these different types
of tests to ensure that the application does what the customer wants
(and that you are happy that it can provide these features).

Why are you now testing with HTTP-Unit? Is it to see if the application
(rather than individual class) is working as the customer wants? The
answer to that question might indicate whether you are on the right
track.

Hope this helps!

Andy.
